_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Guardian Energy Hankinson
RMP Executive Summary
August 2023

This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan ("RMP") for Guardian Energy Hankinson (Guardian Hankinson).  Guardian Hankinson is a dry mill fuel-ethanol production facility located in Hankinson, North Dakota. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations ("CFR") Part 68 and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.

The Guardian Hankinson facility is subject to the RMP rule due to storage above threshold quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance.  This is an update to the earlier RMP submittal under Hankinson Renewable Energy, LLC and includes a name change to match the parent company Guardian Energy Management, LLC.  Please note, the facility previously was subject to RMP for natural gasoline, a regulated flammable mixture; however, due to previous process changes, they no longer qualify under RMP for this process.  However, the facility retains mitigation measures for this substance, but it has been removed from the RMP program.

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Guardian Hankinson is committed to operating the facility in a manner that promotes both the safety of our employees and the general public as well as being protective of the environment. Guardian Hankinson has adopted and implemented policies and procedures that ensure our operations adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Through the proper design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the equipment and through the training of our personnel, Guardian Hankinson has minimized the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudde

n release of hazardous materials.  In the event that a release does occur, the facility's emergency response actions are described in its Integrated Contingency Plan ("ICP"). The ICP includes procedures to coordinate response actions with local emergency response personnel (i.e., law enforcement, fire, and rescue departments, emergency medical services, hospital and government personnel, etc.) as well as any potentially affected neighbors. In addition, the ICP is used to familiarize local emergency response personnel with the types of material handled and company-specific emergency response procedures.

2. Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled
The Guardian Hankinson facility is a dry-mill fuel ethanol fuel production plant capable of producing approximately 170 million gallons of anhydrous ethanol annually.  Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through a continuous fermentation and distillation process.  The RMP regulated substance stored at the facility is anhydrous ammonia, which is used for pH control and as a nutrient in the fermentation process.

3. Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
As required by EPA, Guardian Hankinson has established programs to address accidental release prevention measures and notification requirements of Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations.  In addition, Guardian Hankinson has established programs to address the process safety management (PSM) requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration ("OSHA").  These programs are summarized below.

3.1. Employee Participation
Guardian Hankinson has developed an employee participation program that ensures employees have access to all process safety information, results of any process hazard analysis (PHA), results of any incident investigation, results of any compliance audit, current operating procedures

, current emergency response plan, and records of any management of change.

3.2. Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information
The facility utilizes the HAZOP PHA methodology. The PHA identified potential major hazards, including toxic gas release, flammable liquid fire, vapor cloud explosion, storage vessel over-pressurization, equipment failure due to corrosion, release of hazardous materials due to over-filling and/or loss of containment.  The facility utilizes process controls such as vent collection systems, pressure and vacuum relief valves, in-line check valves, manual and automatic shutoffs, automated interlocks, operating level alarms, operating procedures, grounding and bonding equipment, rupture disks, and excessive flow devices to prevent or limit releases.  Guardian Hankinson keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) and the Emergency Response Action Plan. The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, and piping and instrument drawings ("P&ID").

3.3. Operating Procedures and Training 
Guardian Hankinson maintains written operating procedures that address all modes of process operations, including normal operations, manual operation, regeneration, and emergency shutdown. The facility has developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in facility operations.

3.4. Contractors
The contractor safety procedures establish minimum guidelines and activities in order to assure that contractor personnel follow safe work practices and procedures. The procedure includes a contractor screening proce

ss and hazard awareness, safety and emergency procedures training, and safe work permitting that includes hot work and fire prevention.

3.5. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
Guardian Hankinson conducts a pre-startup safety review ("PSSR") for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing equipment into service.

3.6. Mechanical Integrity
The facility's mechanical integrity program includes written procedures, training, and regular inspections and equipment testing to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems and controls in safe operating condition.

3.7. Management of Change
The facility's management of change (MOC) program reviews all proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change.

3.8. Incident Investigation
Guardian Hankinson has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a release of a regulated substance. The procedure establishes the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases. Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.

3.9. Compliance Audits
The facility will conduct audits of the provisions of RMP and PSM to verify that procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed.  The audit will include a revie

w of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.

4. Five-year Accident History
The facility has not had any accidents reportable under RMP. This RMP submittal is an update to a previously submitted plan.

5. Emergency Response Program
Guardian Hankinson maintains a written emergency response program in its ICP that includes an Emergency Response Action Plan and the Facility Response Plan. The purpose of the ICP is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The ICP addresses aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Guardian Hankinson has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures when first assigned to a job and on a recurring basis to ensure they can perform their specific emergency response duties.  Guardian Hankinson coordinates emergency response activities with the local fire departments and third-party emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan. The emergency response program will be updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The Guardian Hankinson facility has been designed and constructed to meet existing construction and process safety requirements.  Guardian Hankinson will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility. At the time of this RMP update, there are no immediate changes planned to improve safety.
